narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned various new grammar structures, vocabulary, practiced speaking skills.
I learned more conversation Korean.
My ability to speak and understand Korean has improved immensely. I've also learned a lot more about Korean music, both within and outside the genre of K-pop.

Through taking this class, I was able to expand my Korean proficiency through Korean popular music. Since I already enjoy listening to Korean music, this was a useful way to incorporate an interest of mine to help my Korean improve.
Further Korean vocabulary and grammar structures as well as Korean popular culture

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths:   is the kindest most understanding professor. She brings so much warmth to every class and has been really understanding of all the weaknesses that have come with this semester. I really appreciated how she adapted the course so there were no tests and more recorded assessments like videos/audio, other projects, etc. Weaknesses: it's just generally hard to have a language class over zoom. It's harder to comprehend things and ask for clarification, etc. especially in a higher level language class.
I think students learn much better through art (music, poetry) and the professor did a great job of incorporating art into the class.

A strength of this course is definitely Professor Lee-Smith. She's AMAZING! She's incredibly considerate of her students and wonderful at explaining new grammatical concepts and any points of confusion. Sometimes, I had difficulty holding myself accountable to study without quizzes, so a few assessments like that might be helpful. But otherwise, the course is so fun!

A strength of the course would be the interactive learning format. Professor Lee-Smith used a variety of means to get her students to practice their Korean whether that be hosting "DJ podcast" discussions, writing our own Korean sentences, or making our own Korean song lyrics.
It would have been nice to spend more time learning new grammar patterns as opposed to reviewing past ones.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Successes: using alternative forms of assessment like making a TED talk recording, writing our own songs, putting all homework assignments on a Google doc. breakout rooms were great!!! Allowed for easier discussion. Areas for improvement: maybe we could clarify at the beginning of the class how we should volunteer. For example, sometimes it was unclear whether we should just go ahead and talk or raise the blue hands through zoom or physically raise our hands.
Limiting the number of examinations increased my day-to-day engagement with the class.

I think the class worked as well as it could have over Zoom. Sometimes, there were connectivity issues, etc., but Professor Lee-Smith handled those issues gracefully and compassionately as they arose. I think that her amazing attitude was the most important thing.
N/A
The project-based learning played out very well in a virtual setting!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!  makes such a caring learning environment and is a wonderful professor.
Yes! It's a very relaxed environment to learn in and any class with the professor is time well-spent.
Yes! Definitely! I've already recommended it to all my friends learning Korean. It's so much fun, and Professor Lee-Smith is wonderful.

I would recommend this course to any student wishing to improve his or her Korean proficiency. Although I do have to add that because the class only meets 50 minutes three times a week, it is up to the student to dedicate time everyday to study Korean. Moreover, given the relatively low amount of actual speaking practice that we got (being that the class only meets three times a week), this should not discourage prospective students but rather encourage them to seek creative ways to practice speaking.
I would recommend if you want to continue learning Korean.
